title: 106_hr1426
content: The Act titled "Money Laundering Prevention Act of 1999" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 outlines the findings and purposes of the Act. The Congress finds that money laundering is a significant issue, with billions of dollars being laundered annually, especially in connection with the illicit drug trade. US financial institutions play a crucial role in combating money laundering, particularly through private banking services catering to wealthy clients. The Act aims to prioritize combating money laundering in US financial institutions, close gaps in law allowing money laundering in private banking, designate high-intensity money laundering areas, and consider money laundering activities in bank holding company applications. Private banking services are estimated to have assets between $200-300 billion and are vulnerable to use by drug traffickers for money laundering. The Act prioritizes combating money laundering in US financial institutions, including private banking activities with assets between $200-300 billion. The Act requires the Secretary of the Treasury to submit a report on private banking activities in the US within a year. The report should cover the nature and extent of these activities and regulatory efforts to ensure compliance with relevant laws. Private banking activities include personalized services for high net worth individuals, such as money management and investment advice. Depository institutions must have policies to ensure compliance with relevant laws. The amendment requires financial institutions to maintain account information to prevent money laundering through concentration accounts. The regulations mandate associating account holder names and numbers with all account activity for supervision and law enforcement purposes. SEC. 5. DESIGNATION OF FOREIGN HIGH-INTENSITY MONEY LAUNDERING AREAS. This section adds a new part to address International Money Laundering and Related Financial Crimes in the United States Code. The Secretary, in consultation with Federal banking agencies, will develop criteria to identify foreign areas with concentrated money laundering activities. Any foreign country meeting these criteria will be designated as a high-intensity money laundering area, with notifications sent to relevant financial institutions. The Secretary, in consultation with Federal banking agencies, will develop criteria to identify foreign areas with concentrated money laundering activities. Any foreign country meeting these criteria will be designated as a high-intensity money laundering area, with notifications sent to relevant financial institutions, including depository institution holding companies. The notification will include the identity of the designated country and a written warning about the concentration of money laundering activity in that country. SEC. 6. Double the criminal penalties for violations involving high-intensity money laundering areas. SEC. 6 amends Section 5322 of title 31, United States Code, to allow for doubling of penalties for violations involving high-intensity money laundering areas. The amendment applies to violations committed on or after the enactment of this Act. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to include a new paragraph regarding money laundering. The Board must consider the effectiveness of companies in combating money laundering, and cannot consider applications involving companies under federal investigation or prosecution for money laundering. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to disapprove applications involving companies found liable for money laundering or related financial crimes in the 5-year period before consideration by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. This amendment applies to applications submitted after December 31, 1997. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to disapprove applications involving companies found liable for money laundering or related financial crimes in the 5-year period before consideration by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, if the application was not approved before the enactment of this Act.
